Authors:
Ralph Daniel Mangelsdorff, Ulrich Meve, Sigrid
Liede-Schumann
Title:
Phylogeny and Circumscription of the Antillean Genera
Tylodontia Griseb., and Anemotrochus Mangelsdorff, Meve & Liede
(Apocynaceae-Asclepiadoideae: Gonolobinae)
Journal: Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society
Abstract:
Combined molecular and morphological analysis shows that a
number of small-flowered Caribbean Asclepiadoideae of hitherto uncertain
affiliation form two independent lineages in the Gonolobinae, and not as
previously assumed, in the Metastelmatinae. The genus Tylodontia, based
on T. cubensis, is a small genus restricted to Cuba. Besides T.
cubensis, the genus comprises T. fusculum, a species formerly assigned
to Metastelma; T. urceolata, a species formerly assigned to Astephanus,
and a new species, T. stipitata. The second lineage is described as the
new genus Anemotrochus and comprises the widespread Carribean
Anemotrochus eggersii, a plant formerly placed in Metastelma.
Anemotrochus comprises three species, one of them, A. yamanigueyensis,
discovered by the authors in Eastern Cuba, is described as new. The
inclusion of the third species, A. viridivenius from Hispaniola, a plant
formerly ascribed to Matelea, is supported by both morphological and
molecular data. Tylodontia and Anemotrochus are members of the wider
Matelea alliance, but form lineages independent from each other and from
Matelea.
